EXTRADITION BILL – WHAT COULD HAPPEN TO YOU?

#1 - What is the Hong Kong extradition bill?
- This bill allows the Hong Kong, where is a common law jurisdiction, to extradite any “fugitives” to China, where is a civil law jurisdiction
- The Chinese government can request the Hong Kong government to transfer any “fugitives” to China whom are claimed to have violated the Chinese Law, even though they have not violated any laws in Hong Kong
- This clearly violates the Hong Kong Basic Law, in which Hong Kong people are promised with a high degree of autonomy, including an independent judiciary

#2 - What’s wrong with China’s human rights?
- Liu Xiaobo, Nobel Peace Prize laureate was died in imprisonment in 2017 after he advocated for political reforms in China
- The villagers of Wukan rose against the Chinese government from 2011 to 2016 as their properties were sold by government to real estate developers without a proper compensation. The protest was suppressed and its major leaders were sentenced
- Around a million Muslims are now detained in re-education camps in Xinjiang just because they hold a different religious belief

#3 - How does it concern you?
- The independent judiciary of Hong Kong protects all its residents and tourists from facing an unfair prosecution and trial
- After the bill has passed, the Chinese authorities can request Hong Kong to extradite anyone to China as long as they claim they are criminals, REGARDLESS OF THEIR NATIONALITIES
- The Chinese government can also confiscate ALL your money in Hong Kong as you are a proclaimed fugitive
- The European Union (EU) has lodged a demarche, a formal diplomatic protest, to express their concern regarding this bill

PART 2

#4 - What do the Hong Kong people think of the extradition bill?
- The extradition bill has sparked great public controversy among Hong Kong people. Organizations and representatives from different sectors have spoken out against the bill
- on Jun 9, 1.03 million people have rallied against this bill, which is 1/7 of the population in Hong Kong
- similar rallies have also found in 29 major cities of the world, including London, San Francisco, Toronto, Berlin, Tokyo, Sydney, and Taipei, which are led by Hong Kong people living there

#5 – How has the Hong Kong government treated the protesters?
- instead of listening to the public opinion and scraping the bill, the Hong Kong government has insisted on passing it within July 2019
- Protesters have been faced with unlawful and inhumane treatment from both the Hong Kong government and the police force
- on Jun 9, some protesters were brutally assaulted and arrested by the police, who were unnecessarily violent toward the protesters
- on Jun 11, youngsters were targeted in subway stations and were forced to stand against the wall and be searched by the police for an hour WITHOUT A PROPER SEARCH WARRANT
- on Jun 12, police officers used pepper sprays and water canons on UNARMED protesters when they rallied outside the government headquarters
- The police had also confiscated food, water, and medical supplies of the protesters on Jun 11 & 12, which could possibly violate the International Humanitarian Law
- Some police officers have threatened to “guillotine” protesters to in their personal social media accounts
